description: Best sushi in the Financial District/China Town area! I am vegetarian and have a hard time finding sushi rolls that aren't just plain avocado, or plain asparagus. I got the Tofu Crunch Roll and the Yam Tempura Roll, and they were both amazing. And they come with soup and salad all for around $10-15. You can't beat that!
author: Julia H.

description:
This is a great place for fast and cheap lunch. Their menu is overwhelming with so many options from sushi, sashimi and combo plates. The place gets packed, so come early. I'd like to describe the service as organized chaos. You order, take the number and grab a table. They serve you quick. Tables are in close zones from each other too, so if you have a personal bubble, you may be uncomfortable. 

I ordered the katsu curry plate with a dragon roll (way too much food). My friend ordered some nigiri and my other friend ordered some tempura and cali rolls. The sushi rolls are basic American rolls and not the best nor freshest I've had. While Japanese chefs do add wasabi to their nigiri, it's very minimal whereas this place packed it on and my friend had to wipe it off. The curry with the katsu wasn't the best either, it was more carrots and veggies than sauce, though it was still edible and quite delicious. 

Overall, this place is a decent place to go to for cheap and quick Japanese food with great amount of portions. Don't expect top quality stuff here, though. I'd come again.
author: Jenna T.

description:
While I was interviewing in San Francisco prior to getting my current job I ended up stopping by here just for a very fast bite in between interviews. 

The sushi was very inexpensive mid line quality that I would highly recommend if you are low on funds and just quickly need a snack. If all you're getting is an avocado roll or CA roll at $5 or less it won't break the bank.

I would not recommend bringing a large group of people here as it is a smaller space that's mainly self serve after ordering, but I found the service to be friendly and welcoming.

All in all, not bad.
author: Meg T.

description:
Not bad if you're in bind and need a reasonable price point. You can get out of there for under $20 a person but it's medium quality cafeteria food that seems to be of Japanese origin. I had chicken udon and it was a piece of grilled chicken, sliced up & put on top of some udon. I don't believe I've ever seen this before. It sort of works & didn't taste bad but its Japanese-ish, not Japanese.  Also had some California Rolls - mayonnaise, imitation crab meat & avocado. ???  Again Japanese-ish.

One other plus is cafeteria style so no one will bother you to ask you to leave.
author: Leung T.

description: Great food clean and busy! Great spot to stop and enjoy some standard sushi!! Thank you!
author: Lisa S.

description: Just the other day I was saying to my wife I wish there was a good teriyaki place near my office... then I walked in here... this was not what I was looking for.  I was excited at first.  The menu is large and they have a lot of things to pair... I had the Beef teriyaki ... it was cooked until there was no juice left and the steak was as tough as leather.... so disapointed... but it is cheap.
author: John F.

description:
Calamari Friday special, crispy!   

I've had this order a few times and it's been consistent and the portion similar.

Check in with your phone # on their pad and get free meals.
author: Drew B.

description:
Food was okay, but pricy for what it was. I got the chicken teriyaki with the nigiri add-on. Couldn't choose what nigiri, no substitutes.

The chicken was burnt and dry, the nigiri was slathered in wasabi. Clearly no passion in the food whatsoever.

Service was quick, though.
author: John T.

description:
BEST CHEAP LUNCH IN FIDI, way better managed than the one on Mission. (haven't tried the one on Spear)

I almost always get a Chicken Donburi for lunch to go, $10 tax and tip included. Box of well prepared rice, chicken terryaki, egg & radish + miso soup + side salad with that gingery sesame dressing. In 3 years in FiDi, I have not found a lunch I liked more at this price point. Takes less than 5 minutes, which gives me time to polish of 2 cups of complimentary tea.

I don't like cheap sushi, but if you're into it they got plenty. Most things they offer have wide tolerances before they are considered bad... and generally for their price points in this hood, you don't complain. aka, you'll probably be very happy with the meal for the $. 

Pro Tip - Stick to the simple things probably prepared in batches... Tokyo Express crushes it on the corporate lunches / trays / bulk orders, so they have a huge economy of scale, helps assure the simple menu items with common components will be legit. For me, that's the Chicken Donburi.
author: Roger L.

description: I ordered the sashimi and tempura combo $17.99. They left out my TEMPURA! Well, thank you for telling me that the chef gave me 2 extra pieces of fish madam. But why didn't you tell me that there was no tempura available?! I would have ordered something else!
author: linda t.

description: Unfortunately, this restaurant is not Japanese owned/operated and truly lacks authenticity.  Not having miso soup as a main item on the menu was a bit of a shocker and a shame for anyone impersonating. It's in Chinatown, so expect to see locals or tourists just happy to experience sushi in the area.  You order and wait similar to fast food restaurants. If that's ok, along with cheap low-grade sushi, then this is surely the place for you. You may want to a pay little extra and get the real-deal elsewhere.
author: Ruby B.

description:
Not a super high quality restaurant, but a pretty good "fast food" Japanese food chain. I would go here over Yoshinoya in a heartbeat. The portions at this place are pretty good. For 9 bucks, you can get, what appears to be a half chicken breast of chicken teriyaki, miso soup, rice, and a salad. For the FiDi, that's pretty damn good.

Their sushi rolls are decently sized and I feel are a tad fresher than sushi that you get at a grocery store. 

Service wise, I've never had a problem. They're prompt, friendly, and overall very helpful. The team that I work with, frequent this place often, and we have never had a problem with our order. 

Overall, if you're looking for a quick bite to eat and you're on a budget, try Tokyo Express. If you're used to places like Hakkasan or Koo, than this place isn't right for you, but if you like to, every once in a while, eat at places like Panda Express or Sushi Boat, this is right up your alley.

Bonus: try their Udon or their daily special! More bang for your buck!
author: Tiffany N.

description: Perfect place for a quick bite. Selection of sushi is just great. Udon noodle soup is good enough to order it again. Once I've had Salmon Donburi and salmon was over fried.
author: Molly H.

description: This is a quick lunch spot to grab something to go or sit down for a casual lunch with friends. All the basic options for Japanese food - nigiri, rolls, teriyaki bowls, noodle soups, etc. The quality is about right for the price paid - les than $15 on average. Daily lunch specials drop some items down by $1-2.    Recommend as a lunch option if you work close by, but otherwise, not a trek worthy destination.
author: Judy C.

description:
After trying a bunch of stuff from Tokyo Express, I've decided that my favorite on the menu is their chicken teriyaki bento box! They make it good here and they give you TONS of chicken. Their chicken isn't dry at all! I kinda wish they would give you a little bit more rice to go with the chicken! Their bento boxes also comes with a salad and miso soup. Sometimes I order California rolls to go with my bento box when I'm in a starving mood.

Tokyo Express is also the cheapest spot in SF Fidi for chicken teriyaki bento box.
author: Alice X.

description:
Some hole-in-the-walls are great, others are just holes. This is the latter. I ordered a tuna hand roll, crunchy California roll, and avocado/cucumber roll. There was something not fresh in the avocado, which ruined both the cucumber and California roll. The tuna hand roll was ok, but nothing great. 

Plus, they had a hard time understanding why I wanted a tuna, rather than spicy tuna, hand roll. They asked me three separate times and then had to check with the kitchen to see if they could "accommodate."  Seriously, am I the first person who has ever ordered a non-spicy hand roll here?
author: Denis S.

description:
Ordered their Salmon Donburi for lunch today. The pickup was online and they gave you a lot, including a salad, a miso soup and the main entree. However, the Donburi is not authentic donburi at all, not even close. There is a sunny side up egg on top of a bed of fresh vegetable. 

The salmon terriyaki is fine on its own but I feel cheated by the name of "Donburi".
author: Athena C.

description: I've only been there for lunch. Their sushi is prepackaged and not terribly fresh. The price wasn't compelling either.
author: Matt S.

description:
Nice to come here when it's cold outside. Their noodle soups warms you up and to make matters better, they are pretty darn good. The last time I came here I ordered the chicken donburi with a side of curry. My one criticism is that the curry could've been better. I think I've been spoiled by Mitsuwa's curries.

Otherwise, small place and quick service, hence the word "express". Really nice staff,  and you can eat inside. They bring the food to you and also bring around your complimentary side dishes. Their service is surprising for a place though it seems like a "fast-food" joint 

Have self serve tea and water complimentary on tap.

I love coming here for a quick Japanese lunch :) I don't come often but when I do, I feel nothing but relaxed and leave with a full belly
author: Melanie G.

description:
This is a small hole in the wall sushi place. That said, they have a convenient location in the financial district and a pretty big selection of sushi, including vegetarian sushi items.

I passed over the vegetarian sushi combination to get two separate rolls - the crispy tofu roll and the classic avocado roll. They were both pretty good and relatively filling for a ~$8 meal.
author: Nishad J.

description:
This was my go-to place for lunch before, but then they raised their prices! Well, to be fair, they did keep their prices low for quite a long time. That's why I used to come here so often, because their prices were the lowest in the area. Now you have to go for the daily specials to take advantage of their previously low prices. I like going on Monday for the chicken udon ($6.59) or Tuesday for the salmon teriyaki rice bowl ($7.37). They also have a good deal on the Chirashi on Friday for $15. Basically, the specials start out cheaper earlier in the week and starts getting more expensive as the week goes on. 

Tip: If you don't like their iceberg lettuce salad with the mayonnaise dressing that comes with many of the meals, you can substitute edamame for free!

Bonus Tip: Pay with the LevelUp app to get $5 back for every $50 spent!
author: Audrey L.

description: Always busy little lunch spot. I order ahead on Eat24 to skip the line. You also get free edamame when ordering over a certain amount. Been meaning to sit down for lunch one of these days. The servers are all sweet, but super efficient.
author: Tiffany M.

description: This is a great spot for fast food sushi. My office has been ordering from here for 5 years though none of us have actually eaten in the establishment. In these 5 years, they have never gotten our orders wrong and they pack our lunches in individual bags with our name and items labeled. Their rolls are of a good size without too much rice and the fish is fresh and they give you decent slices of sashimi. We love their Agedashi Tofu and their Udon, Donburi and Salmon Bento Box are just as tasty. They offer brown rice but not for the sushi rolls. Some of our favorite rolls Francisco Roll, Heaven Roll, and Spider Roll. My vegetarian colleagues and those who don't eat raw can find a number of great things to eat here.
author: Jen L.

description: Why you giving someone a hard time when the person over the phone made the mistake.  It's just salad that were asking for and they gave my wife a hard time!  Have some kind of consideration!
author: Jonathan M.

description: Very good place. Rock-n-roll maki is good. I'd come back again here when hungry. Don't be afraid of line- it's a huge place.
author: Anna R.

description:
For ten dollars you can get a modest serving that includes your meal, miso soup, rice, and a salad. For being within range of FiDi this is one of the best deals you can get. The fish is always fresh, and oh, is it delicious. I would go to say this fish is better than the fish I had at Scoma's across the bay for triple the price.

This is definitely my go-to lunch spot in FiDi over other places, except when I have cash and want to splurge at Cafe Prague. ;)
author: Nijiko Y.

description: The service was amazing. The cashier was pleasant and the waitress was very nice. The food came to us a few minutes after we ordered. The portions were a decent size for the price and while the tonkatsu rice and sushi rolls I ordered weren't the best I had eaten, they weren't that bad either. In fact, it tasted quite good for my standards. Overall, this was a joy. I'd recommend this place for anyone coming here for the first time.
author: Kevin S.

description:
My company catered lunch from here and we had giant party platters of sushi which were surprisingly good with decently fresh fish.

I've had many bad experiences with catered sushi which usually turns out bad, but the ones from Tokyo Express were really good and we finished all of it! There were not much fancy rolls or fancy sushi, but it was pretty decent for catered sushi.

Definitely hope to have more food catered from here in future!
author: Christina N.

description: Quality of food here is above average in fidi and comes out relatively quickly. Their udon is delicious. I come here once a week for their udon.
author: Darian L.

description:
Food is pretty cheap, large portions, and they are efficient However inconsistent at times.

Otherwise its not anything "special."
author: Phantom Of Yel P.

description:
Great food , fast service and great location. It's right across my work and it only takes 10-15 minutes for my order to be ready. I haven't had a bad meal from this place. Would I go back? Definitely 
Highly recommended
author: Shane T.

description:
I'm honestly not sure if they were the people to cater our lunch at work or not, but I was told the food was from Tokyo Express and this was the closest location to the office, soooo this is me assuming that the two places are one and the same.

We ordered many different items from them, but I personally loved the tempura vegetables and shrimp (but this is also hard to mess up, unless the tempura isn't crunchy and is drenched in oil). The edamame was also pretty good, though there wasn't much salt on the soybeans. The sushi was only okay though -- nothing to write home about. The teriyaki was also only just okay.

Decent food, but I guess I'll have to order from them specifically to be sure that this is the same place and give a more specific review.
author: Anna W.

description:
I wish this place was better. I wish it was. I had high hopes for it after seeing how crowded it always is, but it's not great at all.
In fact, it's not even good..it's just okay. Definitely disappointing.
Why do a lot of the places that serve sushi in FiDi serve bad quality sushi? I'm not particularly picky with sushi (although I should be), but buffet sushi is better than the sushi I've had in FiDi.

Even the chicken teriyaki bento box I had was bad. $10 for a giant portion is a good value for lunch, sure. But the chicken was so bland in flavor, and it was dry too. I had to pour a lot of the sauce on the table on it as well as soy sauce to make it edible. I also saw that they have brown rice so I asked for brown rice but they still gave me white rice..

The sushi platter they have is over $20 and is a total rip off.

People on other reviews rave about the giant portion for a good price, which is valid, but I want my food to taste good, not just fill me up.

All in all, 3 stars for me. I wish it was better though..I wanted it to be my go-to lunch place like when I was in college (Sushi Cuisine in Merced, CA was my go-to bento box/sushi place for lunch in college that did everything right).
author: Gabriel D.

description: Great deal! Good food, solid portions, and decent prices (especially for FiDi). It's not going to win any culinary awards but it gets the job done and I'd go back!
author: Emily F.

description: If you want legit Japanese food and in the best quality -  this isn't for you. If you want good quality sushi or bentos for an affordable price here in FiDi, this is the place for you. You can't go wrong on their entrées such as the chicken katsu or tonkatsu plate or the donburi. Fills you up with just $10. Price is decent for the amount you get and I'd say come on a weekday because there's are 2 different selections as daily specials and it's different daily special every Monday through Friday. The weekly specials overall have a good selection of sushi, rice plates and noodle bowls to choose from to fit everyone's cravings. Sushi rolls average $8-15 a roll depending on what you want but it's not bad compared to many of the other Japanese places nearby. If you want to indulge quantity wise but not eat buffet style this is the place.
author: Serena C.

description:
Tokyo Express what happened?  I went there yesterday to order take out.  I ordered tonkatsu and they told me they sold out.  Really at 1:00 PM?  Wow.  So I ordered their chicken katsu special with tempura.  I waited in that stuffy restaurant for 30 minutes for my meal. Normally you are in and out 10 minutes tops.  When I got back to my office, the katsu was cold.  WTF?!?!  It's not fresh.  They had it sitting on some cutting board somewhere until they got around to boxing it up for me.  Everything was cold.  The tempura was overfried.

I've been coming here once and a while for my Japanese fix but unless they hire back the original kitchen staff, I won't be coming back.
author: Wendy H.

description: Easy to order online and take back to the office (and it is nice/comfortable to eat in the restaurant, too). People who work here are really friendly. Sushi is fresh/made to order and the tempura always nice and crispy/non-oily. Love the sake nigiri, vegetable and shrimp tempura!
author: Kate B.

description: This is a great lunch spot.  I always come because it's close to my office, they crank out the food quick, and the food is good.  Solid lunch specials for $10-14 depending on the day.  They pack it up nicely when you take it to go, including soup, salad, and all of the condiments.
author: Jeff B.

description:
Very good place to get a quick take out if you are craving some Japanese food. Their employees are very courteous and fast with the service. 

I recommend their Udon soups (any of them). The broth for their udon is AMAZING. Got to try it to believe me. It has a kick of sweet but also of salty, and it stays in your mouth for a moment. I will say that a legit umami japanese flavor in that broth. 

Again, if you work around the financial area of SF you have to give it a try.

I will give it 5 stars if it were not because it gets very busy during lunch time, like every small restaurant around the area.
author: H C.

description:
When I was a wee little kid, my parents introduced me to Japanese food.  Much to their dismay, I spent the next few years of my childhood wanting to be a "sushi waitress."  Especially if the perks included free green tea ice cream.

Fortunately, those days have passed, and I still love Japanese food (and green tea ice cream).  Which is why it's really annoying when Japanese-hunger-pangs hit me in the middle of the workday, and the closest place to my office is the Floating Sushi Boat place run by Chinese people in the middle of Chinatown.

One day my stomach decided that it wanted some hot noodle soup.  My first instinct was to go to Ramen Underground, but I was too lazy to stop by the ATM first, even though it was on the way.  So I looked up Tokyo Express, saw that you can order online (!) and immediately clicked my way through the website for some tempura udon, Alaska roll (salmon and avocado) and the Heaven roll (spicy tuna, basically).

I placed my order through Seamless (if you're a first-time user, put in X949yT in the coupon box for $5 off!) and they said my order would be ready in about 30-35 minutes.  I headed to pick it up, and they asked for my ID, gave me my food, and sent me on my way.

Unfortunately, I didn't know how long my food had been ready prior to my arrival, and although they were in separate bags, the heat from my udon made my sushi lukewarm, so I had to stick it in the refrigerator for a bit before enjoying.  I sort of wish they'd put my sushi outside or something until I got there.  The udon was good too, and it came with a small salad.  Downside was the price - as with most Japanese places, it's pricey if you order more than your basic bento box.

Total fan of this place, especially when I'm really craving some good ol' sushi.  The only thing missing was the green tea ice cream at the end of my meal.
author: Tori S.

description: Extra large portions. The best sushi ever!!! Nice prices - $100 for four people, plenty of food!
author: Sergey G.

description:
I love this restaurant especially sitting in the booths. Big servings, fast and friendly service. Be warned, get there before 11:30am Mon - Fri to get a booth!

The chicken Katsu rocks
author: Pam H.

description: Great for lunch. Chicken teriyaki is on point and plenty of food. Comes with rice, miso soup and a little salad, all for $9. Can't beat it.
author: Andre O.

description:
Still not a huge fan of this place.  But I've made concessions, as it's the closest Japanese take-out place by work.  This place yo-yo's on the quality and presentation of their food.   Their food always looks nice, but tastes...some days, overcooked, undercooked, underseasoned, oversalted, etc.  

I stick with the bento deluxe, sub out the soup and salad for edamame.  I pay with LevelUp so that saves me some time too.  ($10.99 plus tax).

It's a very small counter area, so that's one of the other draws.  There's a line, no matter how you order.  Although, you get to bust to the front of the lines if you're doing pick-up...but sometimes, you end up standing in another line, waiting for your food!
author: Fannie S.

description:
I like it!  The sushi is made fresh to order, its fast, its priced right and delicious.  

I will be back for more...
author: Jenny T.

description: I yelped many sushi places near my work and just decided to give Tokyo Express a try. I had a craving for fried goyza and edamame. I walked over and thankfully I had beat the lunch rush. I ordered a small order of fried goyza which wasn't bad but instead of frying it normal it was like a fried tempura goyza so it tasted a little off. The miso soup was good, the edamame was also good and a small order was more than enough. I also had the fried California roll, i was a little disappointed because it wasn't all fried, just some tempura on top of the rice. Not what i really expected but I didn't get sick and i was satisfied with my meal at the end.
author: Irma R.

description:
I love sushi and maybe I'm just a sushi brat. I love trying different places. My bf lives in the city so you would expect a good part of sf would have fresh fish to serve.

out of all the times I've eaten sushi this is the first time i EVER threw up. at first it tasted good but i was super hungry so everything tastes good when your hungry. after about 3 pieces of my dragon roll i felt a rolling in my tummy. i was thinking it might have been me being hungry and finished the whole thing.

boy was i wrong. after i finished i sat around for about 5 minutes and threw up. i felt sick. i had been food poisoned and felt sick the whole day. my bf doesn't think it was this restaurant is what made me get sick and wants to revisit it.

i definitely dont think so after throwing it up. hell to the fucking no. i wasn't even drunk.
author: Lynn C.

description: Place is great for lunch. It's fast, cheap (~$8 for a bento), and you get a ton of food. I usually stay away from bento boxes because you get a couple pieces of over fried chicken and tempura and you never feel full. I got the chicken katsu with a side of tempura and both were perfect and not greasy. My coworker got the "bento" and opted out the side of tempura. She ended up getting a whole plate of chicken teriyaki and walked away with leftovers.
author: Cindy A.

description:
Food:
Got Sushi Combo A:
Salad: not enough dressing, one of my lettuce was oxidizing!
Miso: standard
Sushi: okay portion for the price, fish is not the freshest, not that I expected fresh fish from a place called "Tokyo Express." Cali roll wasn't good.
Overall, MEH, but they gave me alot of ginger, more than enough soy sauce packets and wasabi.

Price: could be better but standard for FIDI, I guess.

Service: only got takeout but they seem friendly.
author: Emily C.

description: Ate lunch here. Friday special was  charashi $15 with soup and salad. A little crowded at noon when office workers are lined up for take out. We manage to get one of the few eat in tables. Charash had rice, raw salmon, tuna, yellow tail, egg, roe with seaweed and daikon shreds. Nice looking bowl and tasty. Removal of dirty dishes was fast and efficient. No parking so this place is meant for walk ins.
author: Clifford W.

description:
I didn't realize Tokyo Express was a chain, but I've been to the one by the metreon and love it! This ones the same but a little smaller and more Japanese restaurant looking. 

Got the double salmon roll and it was great! Love when they out lemon slices on top. Also got a miso soup and we split edamame. All great! Love this place for a quick yummy lunch or dinner.
author: Alexandra W.

description: This place is really good. I can't get enough of it. The staff is wonderful and helpful. Attentive. The Sushi is to die for. LOVE LOVE LOVE Tokyo Express
author: A·non·y·mous X.

description:
My new favorite lunch spot in the city... i love that you can order online and just walk in and pick up.  the food here is always tasty.  I love that you can add a 6 piece california roll to your meal for dirt cheap (I think it's like $3 extra or something).

convenient, fast, and very good.
author: Marylouise R.

description: 3.5 stars. Quick service and reasonably-priced, fresh food. This is one of my lunch places during the work week and although their sushi rolls are somewhat on the smaller side, I like that I'm able to get my order in and out quickly. Plus they include a small side salad and miso soup with most lunch combo orders. This place also gets my vote for the location and convenience factor. It is always crowded for lunch with other people on lunch break in the FiDi, but wait time has never been an issue due to their quick service.  They do great office catering and delivery as well.  I like their udon soups and rice bowls too.
author: Vinh T.

description:
After having been introduced to this sweet lunch spot by a coworker, I am a convert!  They have a great selection of daily specials that range from sushi combo rolls (dragon, spider, spicy tuna, rainbow, crunch rolls, etc.) to udon, katsu or teriyaki.  I love their sushi combo special because it comes with miso soup and a salad.  

The lunch special is huge - I can never finish it!  And the rolls and salad have always been super fresh and miso soup is delicious.  I have not ordered rolls from the menu, but it's on my list.  

If you are picking up your food, I'd suggest you call in advance to place your order as the place tends to get busy during the lunch hour.  

The prices for their lunch specials range from around $7 to $11.  They accept credit cards.

There is free tea you can sip on or take it to go while you wait to pick up the order.
author: Irena P.

description:
My vision of a bento box lunch usually involves smiling Norii cat whiskers on rice balls, bunny carrot cutouts and teeny teriyaki chicken wings.

A giant rice plate complete with tempura veggies with a side salad and miso soup in their  own plastic containers?  That, my friends, is American-sized bento.

Not that I didn't mind.  I was hungry anyway, so I was glad to try this place recommended to me by a coworker.  So I called in an order of the beef teriyaki bento lunch.  Added one order of hamachi on the side just for fun.

The restaurant was packed but moving well enough.  They sure know how to handle a lunch crowd.  I took my order back to the office and dove in.  It was ... decent.  The teriyaki was okay but the rice was underwhelming.  A bit too sticky.  The tempura was better - nice and crispy.  Not too salty, thank goodness.  I liked the salad dressing.  Mental note - ask them next time what it is made of.

As for the hamachi, it was a good size.  Good texture too.  I would have preferred a bit more seasoning on the sushi rice, but that's being nitpicky.  It was better than the beef.

Overall, not bad for a bustling lunch spot run quite efficiently.  I'd go back and dine in.  It's a good workday lunch spot.
author: Eileen P.

description:
You want cheap sushi that's actually good? This is the place to go! Perfect if you work in the Financial District and you want to grab a quick bite.  We ordered to go and they were super fast.They have awesome lunch specials and you get a ton of food for cheap! Sushi was fresh and delicious! 

Conveniently located a few blocks from my work + delish sushi + quick service + lunch under $10 = I'm sold!
author: Suki B.

description:
My boyfriend decides to take me to this "secret" spot where he was raving about their delicious udon. The restaurant seems a bit worn down. Nonetheless, it still carried its cute Asian charm with the Japanese curtains to hanging over the dividers for the booths against the right side of the room. 
 
With the line moving swiftly, we were ordering at no time at the front register. I was a bit disoriented from all the options clustered onto the huge white backboard. Imagine looking at a menu pamphlet with a pictures of sushi and a caption underneath. That is how the backboard looks like. Overwhelming, but thorough and impressive.  

I ordered the tempura udon and received a numbered placard to carry back to where ever my boyfriend chose for us to sit. 
 
They have that sesame-tasting tea for you on a shelf as well as water to bring back to the table.  
 
They gave us a small side salad with thousand island mix dressing. We noticed that others received miso soup alongside their salad. Of course, our udon orders do not include a side of soup.  For future reference when I order their bento box, you get soup at no additional cost!  
  
My udon did live up to my expectations. It had perfect texture, the tempura was a great addition to each spoonful of noodles. I had to have my boyfriend finish the rest of my bowl because I was that full.  

Yay! New addition to my favorite lunch spots near work.
author: Becky Q.

description:
(See pics)

Yes it's very crowded but people eat and go so if you wait for a minute or 2 you will find a table. I also realized even at times when I only order my noodle soup they would give me the salad, which I find to be very nice!
author: T L.

description:
I was in the mood for fresh sushi and my friend told me about this place so I checked it out.  It is quite small but also very cute with its Japanese decor.  This place was packed!  I don't know if it was because people were using PAGO credits or if this place is usually this crowded but be prepared to bump into folks and knock over a few cup of teas (ok, kidding about the last part). 

 I ordered Spicy Tuna Roll and California Crunchy Roll and in about 15 minutes my order was ready.  I found an empty table and sat down to eat because I was starving.  The sushi was fresh and really good.  I also like how this lady walks around and checks on you to make sure everything is ok.  She came by and brought me a nice cup of hot tea and some water.  

Overall, the sushi is good and it's made right when you order it.  This place gets really packed and seating may be difficult to find but overall, this is a good place for fast, fresh sushi!
author: Cynthia P.

description:
I usually end up getting a beef udon soup with a 6pc California Roll. They're pretty consistent getting your order done on time and having it nice and hot. This is not a place I go to religiously but if i am craving udon soup I usually get it from there. You can actually check out my review for Tokyo Express on my blog site along with other udon dishes:

http://thenoodleguy.com/2012/02/28/tokyo-express-restaraunt/

http://thenoodleguy.com
author: Vernon V.

description:
I am not sure why there are negative perceptions.  I am not sure what folks expect from a place with "express" in the name.

I ordered a Chicken Don bowl and a vegetable tempura.  Both were actually quite good.  The egg was a little overcooked in the don but that is a minor complaint.  It was steamy hot and fresh.  The tempura was light and had very little taste of oil.

It was very quick and the people working there were friendly.
author: Mark D.

description: I really wanted to give this place a four, it was highly recommended by a co-worker, but their lack of vegetarian options hurts. I was in the mood for some vegetable udon, but their broth is made w/ fish and they didn't have an alternative that I could eat. So I ended up settling for the vegetarian sushi combo, which for $10 was a reasonable amount of sushi but it wasn't enough to amaze me. But one of my friends at work probably comes and eats here three times a week, and he loves it. So it's still probably worth checking out.
author: Amaresh S.

description:
The food's decent, but it's great considering the location in the FiDi. There's a reason why it's "express," but definitely not the worst I've had. Apparently you can order online? Which would be a huge advantage so you don't have to wait in line and you can actually read a menu.. I could barely see the menu til I got up close but then was rushed into ordering.

Got the Salmon Donuburi with a California Maki on the side for a total of just under $10. The California Maki was decent enough and the Salmon was actually pretty good! Liked the egg in with the donburi although it was a bit overcooked. I would definitely have ordered it without carrots though if I had known ahead of time.. flavors didn't bode well for my taste.
author: Brad Y.

description:
Quick. Fast. and good bang for your buck!

This place is constant on our lunch menu.  You can eat there, but spots are tight and it's a bit crowded.  If you have a table in the main walking areas, prepared to get bumped consistently by traffic. The chicken teriyaki bento box with salad and soup is standard and good.  Sushi is fresh and satisfies those cravings.  It's comfort chinese and an easy place to get a japanese food fix.
author: Natalie G.

description: Our work had sushi platters catered - perfect for the group! A few simple rows and some more dolled up (like the Tiger Roll). I've now had the Tiger Roll for takeout a couple of times on my own. I tried Hopping California, but I think it was a bit too much fried food for me. Tried the Tokyo Tower most recently and it was very good! Quality is OK - not the freshest fish out  there, but definitely not going to poison you. It does seem a bit over-priced for the amount and quality, but I will be back for work lunch every few weeks.
author: Julie W.

description: Salmon was chewy, I don't think I'll go back.  The other ingredients in the roll were fine.
author: Katelyn K.

description: This is decent for a quick fix of Japanese food. I usually get the Teriyaki  Chicken  plate with tempura and a salad.  You also get a small cup of soup when you seat down to wait for your food order to come.  The food amount is good and is filling.  I've been here several times with a friend.  The staff is nice and food is quick.
author: Liz D.

description:
This place is great for lunch meetings.  They deliver within one hour and Winny is very competent.  I like how they can individualize meals with names written not only on the lunch box but also listed on the receipt! The little things that make my job that much easier. (not to mention they do have great tasting food; hence why I have used them twice so far)
I give it a 5 star! Great customer service, prompt and good food!
author: Irela V.

description:
This place is pretty average.  It's a pretty good place to stop by for lunch but I wouldn't recommend coming at 12. My coworker came around 1 for lunch and it was still super packed. I had to stalk a table to get a place to sit. 

Lets start with what we got. 
We got terryaki salmon with rice which was pretty good. It wasn't amazing but it was passable for a quick lunch. We also got this nigiri platter where the fish was pretty fresh. It came with salmon, tuna, hamachi, octopus, and some other fish I can't remember since I didn't eat it. 

Like said before, this place is a average go to place. Their prices are fairly reasonable because it cost around 20 bucks total for my coworker and I. I wouldn't mind stopping by again for a quick lunch during work.
author: Denise L.

description:
Chicken Katsu Wednesdays

Yes, I've been here at least 5 times and each time it was for Katsu Wednesday.  For under $8, you will find a plate piled high with Chicken (or pork) Katsu which easily turns into 2 meals.  Come early because it fills up quick during the lunch hour.  For the quantity of food, it's a solid 3.5 stars.  

Please note, I have no idea how the rest of their menu stacks up and frankly, I don't think I need to.  The Katsu is good enough for me.  :)
author: Lisa R.

description:
I go here for my lunch break around twice a week and LOVE it. The bento boxes are really great and a good deal: miso soup, salad, tempura, california roll, a main dish, and japanese rice, all for $10. I usually can only eat half so i save the rest and have it for lunch the next day. Also, free hot tea!

The inside seating is also nice and pleasant, and you can get a takeout box for leftovers.
author: Mia M.

description:
All things considered, Tokyo Express is solid.  When you factor in the price and the amount of food you get, the value is excellent.  One of the high points is that they're FAST!  Definitely live up the the "Express" part in their name.  It's great for grabbing a quick bite in between meetings or on busy days.  PRO-TIP: CALL IN AND ORDER AHEAD.  For the reasons mentioned, this place gets hit pretty hard during the lunch hour.  However, they're efficient and I'm all about efficiency.  I can usually place my order by phone, walk down, pick up my lunch and be back at my desk in under 15 minutes.  Now that's efficiency!  

I always order the same thing when I come here: the teriyaki chicken.  It comes with miso soup and salad (and brown rice at no extra charge), all for $7.75.  Unlike most places in the FiDi, they don't leave you sad and upset wondering "I wish I had more meat!" No sir, they don't hold punches when it comes to poultry.  I gotta say, they lay it on pretty thick here!  Probably double the portion size you'd get at any nearby teriyaki chicken bowl place.  Part of the reason why I keep on coming back!  They're like the anti-FiDi type-of-restaurant, meaning you can actually get full for under $10.  Shocking, but true.
author: Joe K.

description: I love their salmon donburi. Gets the food out quick, plenty of seats even during lunch time. I'm addicted!
author: Jessica B.

description:
The saying, "it is what it is" applies here. A 3 star rating is a little misleading... I eat here a lot since it's consistent, decent, and right across the street from work. Everything is pretty good here. My old standbys are:

Nabeyaki udon
Sushi Combo B
Sashimori A
Salmon donburi over brown rice
California roll
Jumping tail
author: James N.

description:
As a sushi restaurant I can only give this place 3*; the fourth comes from the fish (snapper) donburi bowl, which is amazing and somewhat unique (I've yet to see it anywhere else). Basically it's a simple pan-fried snapper fillet with steamed vegetables (carrot, zucchini, and daikon), rice, and a wonderful sauce that I've unsuccessfully tried to replicate at home. With soup and salad it's under $9. 

The mystery about this dish, however, is that they only have it on occasion (though it's a permanent fixture on the menu). Most times when I ask for it I'll get some story about snapper being out-of-season, but over three years I've yet to observe any seasonal pattern to its availability. In any case, It's rare availability actually makes me enjoy it that much more.
author: Zain K.

description:
I was going to give this place 3 stars for being a generic cheap japanese  pseudo-fast-food restaurant but when i got my dish, it got downgraded

I ordered a don kastu, and asked if it consisted of chicken cooked with eggs and onions.  I was told yes.

What I was served was ton katu (just fried chicked) with a nasty dry fully fried egg on top.  

Gross

Miso soup might as well been dirty water
salad had huge chunks of lettuce stalk in it (not broken up). dressing was meh.
author: reza n.

description: Only when I really like a place do I yelp it, cheap/good/fast.  Nothing wrong with this place, 5 stars. Need to come here more often.
author: Azman H.

description: I actually come to this place pretty darn often.  The serving sizes are quite large and filling, and the price, at least in my view, isn't atrocious.  My friend thinks that the chicken is not of great quality, but I think it's pretty decent.  While the terriyaki sauce seems a little too sweet, this place is still really good.  I'd definitely recommend the chicken terriyaki donburi if you want something that will hit the spot without making you feel too ridiculously bloated.  Overall, I'm happy with this place, and will return often.
author: Johnny Y.

description:
This is a wonderful Japanese restaurant for the lunch crowd. Always fresh fish and excellent service. Their staff is friendly and so efficient. 

Lots of choices for sushi and rolls. Also, they have a vegetarian menu. 

My company has ordered catering and their food is loved by everyone at the office.
author: Kelly Y.

description:
I used to think of this place as my go-to sushi place during the work week. Yes, it was somewhat hit-or-miss, but the hits outweighed the number of misses, and the misses were not huge. Today was a huge miss.

I ordered two rolls that I have had before and both were disappointing. The Negi Hama was definitely not fresh and tasted fishy. The rice was slightly warm. The New York roll was ok..shrimp was cooked so no worry there, but again, rice was sort of warm. If I hadn't ordered takeout and had eaten at the restaurant, I probably would have gone up and asked for my money back...it was that bad. What is going on?!? 

The Negi Hama roll and the lack of freshness made my stomach turn.  The edamame was not fresh either. The seaweed salad was ok, not great. But at this rate, it may have been the best thing of the meal. $15 down the garbage.  I want to say I won't be back but there aren't too many sushi places that are so close to my office. But I may just have to skip this place and avoid that sick of feeling of knowing I may have just eaten bad sushi.  You never want that to happen....ugh.

Get it together, Tokyo Express!
author: Rosie S.

description:
So I eat here ALL THE TIME, for the following reasons: because it's front door is the back door to the building I work in, they have good lunch specials, and the portions for hot items are huge. ***Notice, nothing about the amazing-ness of the food, reason being that it is mediocre. 

I have tried pretty much everything on the menu (I also order it for catering for my team), and haven't found anything particularly great or gross. I don't really have any complaints (which is rare), but something about this place is just sooo... what's the word? Generic, lackluster, mundane... All of the above. 

The price isn't crazy for what you get (soup and salad with every meal for under 10$), if you sit in house, you get free tea, and the Chicken Teriyaki bento box is enough for 2 servings. I generally choose the hot items over the sushi from here unless I'm ordering it in large quantities, just because it lacks passion and is a bit pricier then I'm willing to pay for average sushi. The udon never disappoints. 

If you're stuck in the Fidi like me, not a bad place to be.

***Update:  I figured out what Tokyo Express's sushi reminds me of... MALL SUSHI!!!
author: Brandy B.

description:
This is my to go to sushi place when I'm in the mood for fresh and yummy sushi.
It's small and can get really busy during lunch. I recommend coming earlier to avoid the crowd. I had order the Salmon Teriyaki Bento for Lunch. It was good and the price is okay. I have also ordered the Nigri Deluxe Platter for small group meeting and everyone enjoyed it.
author: FarmieK P.

description:
Very dependable place for lunch. Both take-out and a sit-down meal are fast, and you're nearly certain to get a seat since most patrons seem to do take-out.

Love the easy/free tea refill area and the portion size. I had a chicken teriyaki during a sit-down meal and was pretty shocked with the amount of chicken I received.
author: Yan K.

description:
Trying out new lunch time places in the FiDi, I returned to Tokyo Express for my second visit ever.

I consider this type of establishment - half service.  You go to the front and order, get your number placard, take a seat, and your food is brought to you.  While you wait, you help yourself t tea and water at your own leisure.  There might be a mad scramble to find a seat/table right after you pay, and this can be a bit daunting.

I ordered the Chirashi, 'different fish over sushi rice bowl,' ($12.99), my sister ordered the Blossom Chirashi, 'tuna, salmon, avocado over sushi rice bowl,' ($12.99), and my colleague ordered the Vegetable Don ($5.99).  All of our orders came with miso soup and small salad.  

Overall, the prices aren't too bad.  They aren't overly priced, and they can be cheap since you aren't paying for the service here.  They do offer an array of Japanese food, as well as sushi and rolls.  My chirashi bowl was filling.  I didn't count how many slices of fish, but there was a good amount that covered my rice.  The fish wasn't the highest quality, but it'll do for a fast workday lunch.

As other yelpers mentioned, this is an 'express,' so they are quick to clean up your table as you finish your soup bowl, salad bowl, etc.  At times, the way they start rearranging your plates to make room can be a bit overbearing.  But I guess they are aiming for efficiency and not politeness.

For vegetarians out there, they offer quite a selection of veggie options, from rolls to entrees.  And they are easily noted on the menu.  Because of their huge menu, they also have a bunch of handwritten specials written all over the place. Good luck trying to read it all before ordering.  

Overall, I would return if I'm craving a decent Japanese lunch - from a bento box to sashimi, I would go back.  I wouldn't rely heavily on the sushi though, but I'll take their Japanese food, that's for sure.

Side note:  If you aren't ready to order because you're still perusing their big ass menu selection, step to the side or let the people behind you know that they can go on right ahead.  The cashiers are super anxious to take your order, so let them do their job with someone else who is ready.
author: Teri C.

description:
I have new found respect for Tokyo Express.  Prices are still high, but what do you expect right?  It's in the FiDi.  Sushi rolls are still small, but again what do you expect right???

Anyhow, my new found stem from their udon!  The broth is not overly msg-sy.  big plus.  And I actually liked the broth.  Udon noodle has nice texture.  I usually get the Nabeyaki udon.  Pretty good portion of goodies in the bowl, grilled chicken, fish fillets, shrimps, fish cakes, spinach, tofu, and half a egg.  Pretty tasty stuff!  I top my noodle off with japanese 7 spices chili powder, ooOo I want that at least once a week.  

Occasionally I would get the seafood udon.  No egg, but plenty of seafood.  Yum!
author: Gigi T.

description: 3.5. The cheapest and most decent place around my area. The salmon bento is always good and their sushis aren't bad. Order to go and ready to pick up in about 10 to 15 minutes. They are always busy. It's not the best sushi, but cheap, fast, and satisfies the tummy.
author: Karen H.

description: I've been here several times and enjoyed the food, but today I treated myself to a bnig whack of my favorite sushi, and I am pleased to report that it was really amazing. Most places can't get saba nigiri right -- theirs was over the top! HIghly recommended for either a quick FiDi lunch or a mellow late afternoon munch.
author: Dan S.

description: If you want a quick and easy Japanese lunch, this place is the spot to go around FiDi. They have a good menu with the usual suspects you would expect from sushi to donburi to bento boxes. Not the best quality but that is a sacrifice worth making for the speed and low prices. Food is fresh and freshly made and you can get back into your office or cubicle in a short time. That is if you avoid the crowd this place can generate on a daily basis.
author: Ed L.

description: Ususally packed with FiDi employees, Tokyo Express is a great place to grab good and reasonably priced Japanese food. They offer weekday specials and most of their meals come with miso soup and salad. Portions are very generous. I suggest the tempura udon or the chicken teriyaki bento which are delicious and filling. Tokyo Express has their menu online so anytime you need to grab lunch, you can call in, place your order and pick it up 10 minutes later!
author: Maya S.

description: A reasonable, tasty and fast lunchday sushi joint.  Food's solid (rolls ad tempura), service is very friendly and you'll be back at your desk chomping before you know it.
author: Christian C.

description:
I cannot come here any more.  I've realized that after I eat here I suffer from some sort of MSG-infused deadliness which leads to my mouth puckering up and completely drying out no matter how much water I suck down.

See ya around, Tokyo Express.
author: .Hon H.

description:
I come here for lunch sometimes and the rolls are pretty good. I've also had their chicken donburi. Rolls are fresh and delicious. Wait time isn't too bad and rather fast for freshly made rolls. Just peek in and take a look at the line. If there's a line, you might have to wait a bit. However, you can always just order ahead of time.

Yesterday for about $10 dollars I got the dragon roll with a 4 piece CA roll. My lunch also came with a Japanese salad and miso soup. Not bad. Some of the nearby sushi places are cheaper for lunch, but I enjoy the variety and location of this place. Pretty healthy feel to their lunches and I always end up full from their lunches.

Conveniently located by public transit (MUNI 8X, 1) and only a brief (10 minute walk) from Market Street off of Montgomery Bart station. 

A great place for lunch. It's also rather clean and I enjoy the variety in their daily lunch specials. Yummy rolls!

Payment: Takes credit card! ++ points.
author: Tina C.

description: Great food, Great price. crowded put worth it! Just went today and got my free $10.00 lunch via LevelUp!!
author: Kandi G.

description:
This is my GO-TO place when I'm craving tempura for lunch.  I always get the Prawn & Vegetable Combo Tempura, comes with salad, soup, and rice.  I Love it. It fills me up. I spend less than $9.  Their sushi is very good here too.  We've ordered sushi trays from here for our office parties and everyone loves it . 

It does get packed during lunch time (noon), but I always phone my order in and it's ready when I get there.
author: Maribel S.

description: Very fresh fish.  Had the sashimi plate.  Decent pieces of fish yellowtail, salmon and tuna.  Miso soup was delicious.  Edamame was served (oddly) cold.  Not overly special all in all.
author: Jeff S.

description: Had the special of the day..."Calamari Tempura"...when the  dish came out I thought it was  order of Burger King onion rings....same size, same breading, same color.   The rings were chewy and tasted like fish.....good fresh calamari would not be this fishy.
author: Jerry W.

description: This is a very low cost sushi option.  The deluxe bento box will get you most of the things they serve if you want to try that out.  Service is brisk but not impatient.
author: Anthony J.

description:
I am a fan for sure - quick fast and relatively cheap Japanese food during lunch when I have enough time to dash and go back to my desk. I really like the diversity of the menu and depending on my mood they seem to have specials to please me. 

I typically get the Dragon/California roll combo (9.99) which comes with soup/salad. It's the perfect amount of sushi and if you want you can get your tea to go - extra points there for sure. 

Great place to check out if you work in the financial district and have never been. Be warned this place fills up quickly as in today I went in at 12:00 sharp and the place was packed. You may want to get there by 11:45 if you want to eat in. 

Fresh food and nice people combined with the fast service will keep me coming back for more and more while I am working in the city!
author: Heidi S.

description:
My friend and I decided to grab Japanese food today. I suggested this restaurant that I always walked by but never went in. It always looked busy - so that's a good sign. It's a cute restaurant with tables and booth. We went into the restaurant and we waited....just stood and waited by the door. The waiter finally looked our way and I said "table for 2 please". Well apparently it's not one of those kind of restaurants. We actually have to order & pay first, then they give you a number and they bring you the food. Oops. Wish I known that before I stood there like an idiot. 

We both ended up getting the deluxe bento box ($10.99). I got the salmon teriyaki, and my friend got the chicken teriyaki- all deluxe bento boxes comes with vegetable & shrimp tempura, salad, soup, rice and your choice of either sashimi, sushi (2 nigiri's & 3 pieces of California roll), or 6 pieces of California roll. Everything was pretty good - the sushi was so-so - prob not the freshest or best sushi I've had, but it was alright. You can get a self-service hot tea or ice water too on the side. Overall, food came out quickly, it was pretty good, and good portions.
author: Betty S.

description:
Great place for a quick bite.  Better to come earlier because it gets crowded pretty fast.

I usually order the chicken teriyaki bento with tempura.  It's a lot of food and very reasonably priced for the area.  Sometimes the chicken is overcooked, but it's hit or miss.
author: C G.

description:
I'm not sure if it was just my experience, but the number listed here (which is the same as the one on their take out menu) just gave me a busy signal forEVER.  I called a couple times, too, because I hate waiting for a to go order in the restaurant.  Feels like a huge waste of time...and since this place is crammed already you feel like you're constantly in the way and being bumped while waiting for your order.  Sounds awesome so far, right?

Out of all of the "convenient" sushi places I've tried in the Financial District area this one has been my favorite.  Ranks way above the couple on Kearny St. that I have tried.

I got a sushi and sashimi "special" for $14.99 which included 2 unagi nigiri, 2 sake nigiri, and 2 maguro nigiri.  I also chose the maguro sashimi (it came with 6 pieces).  I specifically asked for no wasabi IN the nigiri and they followed through! That's always half the battle for me, I hate having a big ol' glob of wasabi in my nigiri.  The unagi was pleasantly bone free.  

I have also eaten in the restaurant as well and it is a pleasant, though somewhat loud, experience.  I can't remember what roll I got that time but I remember liking it a lot, and my Japanese lunch buddy liked her order as well.

This place is relatively inexpensive and you can get in and out pretty quickly so it makes for a good lunch spot if you work in the area.  Otherwise, I probably wouldn't go out of my way to come here.
author: Mary O.

description:
They have definitely perfected the lunch rush! Located in the Financial District and literally, a 45 second walk from where I work...this is a perfect lunch location!

The lines move fast, the food comes fast and best of all, there's tea to go on the left hand side! 

I have to admit though, the portions are a little on the small side but they have a lunch combo that comes with soup and salad that range from 7.95-9.95. Pretty affordable if you ask me!
author: Vikki K.

description: I used to love this place - quick, cheap and great tasting which is pretty amazing for the Financial District! Sadly they have raised their prices recently which really disappoints! Sushi still tastes good and was decently quick for the lunchtime rush, but wish they wouldnt have increased their prices so much all at once (prices ~6 mos ago used to be about $2 less per roll!)
author: S K.

description:
The teriyaki chicken bento box combo was pretty damn good. Not sure that I'd be begging to come back here day in and day out but maybe that's just because it's fresh in my gut and my stomach is filled to the brim with rice and protein. 

I had a little bit of trouble communicating with the cashiers. I kept asking for teriyaki chicken and they kept pointing me to the box. I was like, but I don't want any of that other stuff, still...box. Then he said to me, "This is your first time here, isn't it." ::exasperated look:: 

Fine, give me the damn box. Just leave out that nasty salad with the iceberg lettuce and red dressing.
author: Julia N.

description:
I haven't eaten rice for about a month now and I was beginning to have withdrawals. Being Filipino, it's almost unheard of not having rice in you daily diet. Without rice I was beginning to fill ill, weak and I was not mentally focused. Well today was the day to fix that and eat some rice and Japanese was the first thing that came to mind. 

I ordered the deluxe bento box from this joint today. Good food, fast service  and decent prices. Unfortunately today I ate alone. I would have loved some company since there was tons of food. I ate about half and got the rest to go. The only complaint that I have is the seats are uncomfortable. They tried to remedy it with a cushion, but it doesn't help.

Anyway, definitely worth checking out ...
author: Jay L.

description: Their online ordering system is pretty efficient. I got the chicken teriyaki bento, total was $7.18. They show how long you need to wait until you pick up your order. I ordered around 12:30 which was rush hour, and they said i could pick it up in 30 minutes. I picked it up at 1 and i felt like i could have picked it up earlier because the food was lukewarm when i ate it. The order comes with rice, miso soup, and salad. I loved the salad, the miso soup was mediocre, and the chicken teriyaki didn't meet up to my standards. Yes, they gave a lot of chicken but it tasted very chewy and the sauce was too watery. I would say if you're desperately in need of Japanese food around this district, come here.
author: Angela H.

description: Your cheaper type of sushi place.
author: Fred G.

description:
Best Sushi in the Financial District. Hands down. I have been to Tokyo Express on several occasions...This place is one of my usual lunch spots. It does it crowded, so be there early or be there after the noon crowd. 

The veggie tempura roll is the most amazing veg roll I've ever ever had. 
I also like the sweet yam roll and tofu crunch maki roll. Recently i tried the House Roll, very tasty I must admit. 

The sushi is fresh, interesting and reasonably priced. 

I also enjoy the Salmon teriyaki and the salmon don...
author: Theresa B.

description: Walked in today, with a lunch order for 6.  I was in-and-out, in 10 minutes!!  They not only bagged each order individually, they labeled them!!  YEAH!!  They're always so nice, even when busy!  Thank You!
author: Charles L.

description:
I've came here many times and I think I should leave them a review.
I love the place, cute and clean. 
The best deal would be their daily specials. My fave is the rainbow roll on fridays. Tried the sushi sashimi combo. Very fresh salmon. Quick service too. It gets packed quickly. So try coming before noon.
author: Di J.

description:
Thanks for the recommendation Spiff E.

Hell yeah! I got a rock'n'roll, spicy tuna roll, miso soup and salad for not even $10 - and it wasn't half bad either. They're rock'n'roll special totally rocks my world and not so much my wallet.
author: Aim E.

description: I eat here at least two times a week. Great sushi and noodles, good prices, fresh ingredients. Their Heaven Roll really does taste like heaven! A great lunch place!!!
author: Ting Z.

description:
If you like the spicy then order the spicy scallop roll here.  Oh lordy lordy!  I couldn't tell you if the scallops were fresh or not because I didn't taste anything but fire on my tongue.  It looked fresh though, so I will have to say that it was.  This is a nice little stop for some quick inexpensive sushi in the FiDi.  They have cute little booths along one wall that are nice to sit with friends and have lunch in.

They have a ton of lunch specials and a very diverse selection of rolls and nigiri to choose from, as well as sashimi and bento boxes all of which are reasonably priced.
author: Luis M.

description:
I go here sometimes for lunch with my friend Marie W. when we are craving sushi.  I only go sometimes because I pretty much crave sushi 24/7... mmm... sushi!

Anyhoo... the food is good, VERY good for the fact that it is a little "fast food" sushi joint.  The fish is fresh, the sashimi is well cut, the portions are really decently sized and their teriyaki chicken is quite the yum.

The problem with Tokyo Express is twofold:
1. The price... who really wants to spend $14.00 on a "lunch special"?  Granted - for good sushi and sashimi I am willing to pay much more than that - but, I can't help but think that when I eat a Yokohama I pay a dollar more for a really huge combo meal.  So, while the portions are decent sized (as in they are large enough to be filling, not so big that you guiltily leave fish on your plate because it's too much - which is a sushi lover's cardinal sin) - the value?

Ain't so good.

2. The service - the service is friendly and attentive... but, in my opinion it shouldn't take a half hour to bring me roughly 10 pieces of salmon sashimi.

How can Marie get chicken teriyaki and fixings (which has to be cooked) 10-15 minutes faster than I get my raw fish?

Just a strange little thing which drives me nutty.
And, given the fact that it's more than half way between my office and home - the delay in service really kind of makes this place some place we only go every once and a while.
author: Kate R.

description: Affordable place with yummy sushi  close to work!  I love this place.
author: Christine P.

description:
This is a great spot for a quick sushi fix.  I agree, it is not the *best* sushi I've ever had, but some days, I want fast and efficient sushi.  This is a great spot for that.  They also have decent udon for days when you want something hot and soupy to fight away the germs.

FYI - They also do corporate accounts and will deliver for big orders.
author: Nikki c.

description:
I'd give this four stars, but it's getting five stars because I'm reading all these reviews where people talk about how much they like it and then give it three. Stingy.

For what it is (a hyper-fast-food-high-volume version of normally slow food), the only comparable one is Sawaii... which is not as good (but faster). Their bentos are really well put together, and they don't seem to use the cheap-o ingredients like  the criminal enterprise known as Sushi-Rock. 

Don't get me started on Sushi-Rock.
author: Edward P.

description:
This hits some of the major points I love finding in sushi: quality (fresh) ingredients and low prices/regular specials.  The only miss is that this restaurant sticks to the basics and does not have many unique, interesting dishes.  A great place for a quick cheap bite, but not for a special memorable meal.

As someone who likes variety my favorite is the maki mono combo.  18 pieces of roll sushi, soup and salad for $10.  The combos, daily deals and bento boxes definitely have sushi on the smaller side, but I've never left hungry from Tokyo Express.
author: Laura K.

description: I have gone there a few times for lunch. The food is good, consistent,  fast, and the portion is genuious. Try to get there before 12 if you want to get seated.
author: Sandra L.

description:
TO GO OR FOR HERE, TO GO OR FOR HERE

you have to answer this first; the ladies at the register won't talk to you unless you answer that question.  crazy ladies. 

just try, it's pretty funny.  I don't succumb to their need to hear a TO GO or FOR HERE, for awhile and they go nuts.

udon is good here.  why would you eat sushi at Tokyo Express then complain about it?
author: Wakako U.

description: I came here for lunch with my mom and brother and we ordered two of the daily specials, udon, soba, and a bento box to go for $43, with lots of left over. One of the daily specials was two kinds of tuna rolls, six pieces each, and the other daily special was an eight piece salmon roll and a four piece California roll. The udon was a good, sizable portion, with lots of veggies. The soba was actually a special for $7 and came with a lot of tempura. The entrees come with salad and miso soup. In general, everything was good, very filling, and reasonably priced. In addition to the bento box, we also took six pieces of sushi to go. The tea is self-serve and very good. I would come back for relatively cheap meal in a pricey neighborhood.
author: Kim D.

description:
Three stars are because of the obvious "fast food" atmosphere.  But, then again, they did name it "Express", and boy, oh boy, do they ever MEAN it!

I really enjoy the food; it's very good for a typical, cheap sushi joint.

Very fast and friendly service.

Decent prices.

I almost always order the bento with beef teriyaki, maguro sashimi and tempura, an extra roll of some sort, edamame and a juice.  Yes, I am a sushi PIG.  I LOVE sushi, so I usually can't get out of here for under $20.  Still, for the big, fat tummy I leave with, that's not bad at all.

(... I see no point in not extending a compliment when I see something pleasant - besides, it makes people feel good) I was in there for lunch last week, dining solo, and looked up to see this absolutely gorgeous little Asian girl (about 5 yrs. old) sitting in a booth a row up from me.  I said to the bus boy "that little girl is beautiful" and he said "that's the owners' daughter".  So darned cute!)
author: Michael O.

description:
Meh.

If it wasn't next door to my office, I'd happily never go here ever again. Alas hunger and convenience occassionally override my brain.
author: Jordan M.

description:
I've been here a couple times during lunch, and this place packs 'em in. It's a relatively small space, but there are enough chairs, tables, and booths to get a good buzz going.  

Order at the register and then find a seat if you're lucky, or I prefer to take away my food and graze in the Redwood Park, just down the road. 

The ordering part takes a bit of patience as you get asked to bend your body from side to side to dodge the servers whizzing by, and the diners on the other.  On the wall behind the register, is a cheerfully lit menu with a large array of tasty choices, so it may take a while to decide what your tummy craves...but once you're at the helm of the line, be sure to know what you want...afterwards, you'll be instructed to "Step to your left", to wait for your Take Away order, or if you're dining in, go look for a table.  All-in-all the food is worth the effort for a good, casual FiDi lunch.
author: Cathy K.

description:
it's the closest sushi place near my work so not much variety when it comes to japanese places for lunch. i usually get the tempura udon or house roll (deep fried yellowtail wrapped in soybean and topped with ponzu sauce and roe). 

come before noon to beat the lunch crowd and make sure you know what you want before you get in line or else you might feel some pressure to order when you get to the register.
author: Helen Y.

description:
I'd give this place 3.5 stars(when will the Yelp people allow for 1/2 stars???). VERY fast service. I felt like as soon as I ordered and sat down, my food was already arriving. That's fast. That's good. I ordered their veggie donburi, which comes with white rice, steamed veggies, some kinda of teriyaki sauce and a fried egg. All for $5.99,  and they throw in miso soup AND a small salad! Seriously, for me, that's a good deal. I also ordered their tempura yam sushi/maki. That was pretty good too. The rice wasn't overly mushy. And, hey, you can't go wrong with anything fried! 
I would definitely go back to Tokyo Express again. They are super fast, super cheap, and have good sized servings. It isn't crazy good sushi. Just good/ok sushi, especially for the price. Oh! and they also have a pretty good veggie sushi selection!
author: Caroline C.

description:
I give this place 4 stars bc I've eaten there and gotten take out.
If you eat there, the service is super fast, if you get take out, be prepared to stand there suckin on your chopsticks for at least 25 minutes. At least that was the case with me.

Good spicy tuna, good rock-n-roll, LOVE their miso and your to-go container is a great re-usable tupperware bin for the next day's lunch adventure.

It's a little tight in there, so you're pretty lucky to snag a table. For about $12 you can get a good, fast meal and then pop back to work. Or not.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Could the place be any more chaotic?  Seriously, don't bother coming here between 11:30 and 12:30 for lunch.  Went there with 3 coworkers and were surprised to find the place standing room only.  

We had plenty of time to figure out what to order standing in line.  But wait, which line is the "ordering" line?  Huh?  They both are?  Then why is that girl calling out names and numbers?  Did I hear someone shout BINGO?!  

There's nothing quite like waiting in line trying to figure out the system when you know damned well that the system is "the person who likes to shove ahead of everyone else gets fed faster."  Or maybe that was my starving stomach talking.

That said, my Salmon Teriyaki bento was delish.  3 ok-sized pieces of well-cooked salmon served in a to-go box with a scoop of rice.  Miso soup, salad with the red gingery vinaigrette.  For something like $9 bucks?  Sure, why not?
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
Their menu is a dizzying array for the new and green so I just ordered whatever my friend got. I think yesterday's lunch special was the chicken katsu bento with tempura (and the obligatory miso and salad). The tempura was heavily breaded but the chicken katsu was quite tender and juicy (hehe fat juices flowing!). Service was fast and efficient and the prices pretty cheap being that it was in the FiDi (haha I really wanted to use that word but alas, I'm still a poser). 

One definitely doesn't look for quality here but for a easy, cheap, and filling lunch, not bad.
author: Annie W.

description:
My buddies from work and I go to this place right around the corner from our office fairly often, and I do have to admit, that the food here is pretty good.  Yesterday, I ordered the chicken teriayki bento box, which came out to be $8.40 after taxes.  You could get a super-delux bento box, which costs $1050 before tax, and it comes w/ California rolls, and some more tempura (includes shrimp, brocolli, potato, and a fried yam).  I've had their rolls here plenty of times and they're actually quite good. 

It's a hit-or-miss luck in terms of if this place is crowded or not.  We were fortunate that it wasn't that busy, especially since we got there right at high noon.  My colleagues always seem to order their vegetable udon, so I'm assuming it's gotta be a pretty tasty soup... hmm.. perhaps I'll give it a try someday.  Probably not though, because I like to have meat in all my main meals.  If you're in the Financial District, and you're craving some decent Japanese food, you should give this place a try.
author: Minh V.

description:
Decent, cheap. Definately white-folk sushi. The "lunch special" is various niigiri and a california roll (aka for people terrified of raw fish).

Semi-reasonable pricing for FiDi, can order online and pickup within 30min.
author: Rebecca L.

description:
Delicious! 

Have gotten a few of their sushi rolls and their Vegetable & Shrimp Tempura donburi meals a few times and loved them. 

Udon soup is plentiful and good but not my fave. 

Whatever they put in their salad dressing is seriously tasty and amazing, and different from other similar-looking Japanese salads I've seen. Don't say it's MSG. It's just thicker and more dressy and less vinegary.
author: karisma r.

description: I have eaten their Sushi Combo B every Thursday for the past many years.  It is always delicious, reasonable quality for the price, and by calling ahead, we can avoid the lunchtime crowd.
author: Jon H.

description: One of my sushi-loving friends loved coming here for the cheapest good sushi around. I was less impressed with their bento box. The meat quality of the beef teriyaki was a bit iffy, and I've had better miso soup.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
You know those weird white circles with pink on the outside that come in some udon varietals and you never really know what they are or want to touch them without gloves? Well, Tokyo Express makes me want to eat them. The place is that good. 

How good is Tokyo Express?

So Good that I go there 4 out of 5 days a week for lunch.
So Good that I don't mind being bounced around like a pinball as their waiters blow by me to serve seated customers while I wait for my takeout.
So Good that I try to rally others in the office to go there for lunch on a daily basis.
So Good that my office smells like udon 24-7 and I enjoy it - in fact, I've created an udon-scented air freshener for my car (not really).
So Good that I proposed to the hostess twice since Tuesday.

You get the idea. Place is good. Nabe-yaki udon is my staple, and never before have I had such high-quality meat, seafood and vegetables in my udon - usually I find Japanese places to throw the knees, beaks, elbows and eyeballs into the soup and hope that the heat, noodles and broth make you forget what you're really crunching. Not Tokyo Express. White meat baby. Real fish. 3 shrimp per order! 

My only qualms - I have to remove the tails of my own shrimp, and the salads taste like cardboard. But hey - the salads are complimentary, and removing the tails has become part of the ritual. 

The sushi is also quite good. I started adding a roll to my lunch order, and have yet to find something that I don't like. I recommend the Hopping Roll, which is a California Roll that's fried like tempura with some teriyaki sauce on top, and a few tobiko just for giggles. It's awesome.

Two thumbs to the sky - hit it up immediately or sooner.
author: Mike B.

description: Good spot for affordable lunch in FiDi. Love the udon noodles and spider roll! Great and fast service too. Takes credit cards which is nice when you'are not carrying cash.
author: Amy N.

description:
I'm a fan of the sushi - anything california and with shrimp is good. I've shared a bento box with another person and it was great. Lunch is always served fast (call ahead if you want a to-go order or be prepared to wait for a seat) and always warm and cheery.

Only complaint is I usually end up spending around 10-12 each trip..eep.

Also - they do deliver if you place a 45.00 minimum.

Good if you need a real quick sushi fix during the work week.
author: laura f.

description:
its actually pretty decent for $7.15 

had the snapper don.  it came with ample amount of fish, fried egg, cabbage over rice.  its got your protien, fiber and carbohydrate.  

its not really a donburi.. where the egg , vegatble and sauce is all over the rice ... but it gets the job done. 

and little flavorless but nothing soy and chili cant fix. 

for 7.15 in the fidi, its a survivor.
author: Doug ..

description: This where I go when I wantnto treat myself to good sushi, and I have never been disappointed. Sure, I've been to better sushi places, but for lunch in the financial district, this place is the best. Fast service, good sushi, reasonable prices.
author: Michele N.

description:
A quaint little place for that in-between take out and sit down kind of meal.  The inside is comfortable enough to enjoy a quick lunch, but you're not going to have to wait forever for your order.

I'm a huge sushi fan and have had just  rolls ranging from $2.00 to $15, and in terms of quality this place is somewhere in the middle, maybe a little closer to the lower end--but in terms of price is around the middle leaning to the upper end.  

$9 though will get you a nice combo plate with a California roll and a few others.  Combine this with a 20-oz beer, or two, which are quite good, and you make for one happy reviewer.

Still, there's nothing too special about this place, except that it's one of the few sushi places in the FiDi.  And, given that it's a half a block away from the office, it is a good bet when we want something different.

On another day I might be kind and give this place ****, but I've been giving out too many of those plate, so *** will do...
author: Tien N.

description: I think the more often I eat here, the more it stands out that I am eating Japanese food "fast food" style.  The miso soup is sometimes much too salty, and served hotter than it should be. The sushi is nothing great and I usually come here only for hot foods.  Sometimes, even the hot foods are not as satisfying as I remember.  I think, I really do miss eating quality Japanese cooking, but I still come here because a) the price is good and b) no matter how many Japanese restaurants I try, my favorite one is still tucked away on a side street in Pleasant Hill, and I'll never find anything better.
author: Shar M.

description:
It's all about managing expectations. When I go to an upscale Japanese restaurant like Kyo-ya, I expect impeccable service and perfect slices of fresh sashimi and sushi.

When I go to the "fast food" Japanese hole-in-the-wall around the corner from my office, I expect mediocre rolls made with sub-par grade fish. So I am highly impressed and very pleasantly surprised when my chirashi sushi arrives with buttery slices of hamachi and salmon that melt in your mouth (the tuna slices were as expected, not so great). It's even topped with a shiso leaf, very authentic.
